Award.AwardTitle: Confinement in Electrospun Polymer-Based Nanocomposites, with Research Opportunities for Deaf and Hard of Hearing Interns
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

Using the electrospinning (ES) technique for processing nano-scale fibers, the effect of confinement on fundamental physical and structural properties will be investigated. Confinement refers to restrictions on the mobility of the polymer chains brought about by addition of fixed barriers inside the fibers. Besides the crystals of the polymer, additives such as carbon nanotubes, organically modified silicates, or silica, lead to formation of nanocomposites in which these nanofillers also serve as fixed barriers leading to chain confinement. The relaxation properties of the nanocomposite are altered, leading to beneficial improvement of properties, for example an increase in the use temperature, and an increase in the mechanical modulus. The phase structure and physical properties of ES polymer-based nanocomposites will be studied as they relate to the fiber orientation, degree of crystallinity, filler type, and amount. The objectives are to: 1. Provide fundamental understanding about the relationship between crystals or nanofillers and the non-crystalline portions of the semicrystalline electrospun nanocomposite fibers, especially through new methods of quasi-isothermal heat capacity analysis and fast scanning chip calorimetry; 2. Correlate the fiber properties (e.g., diameter, crystallinity, chain orientation, filler type, amount, and dispersion) to the degree of constraint; and 3. Separate the confining effects of the filler from those of the crystals. Techniques to be used in the work include high precision, high accuracy heat capacity measurements by temperature modulated differential scanning calorimetry to quantify the level of confinement. For the first time, the techniques of fast scanning chip calorimetry on ES fibers (through international collaboration with the Schick group in Rostock, Germany) will be applied to study homogeneous nucleation in ES fibers. Also for the first time, dielectric relaxation spectroscopy (DRS) will be used to characterize the dipolar relaxations of ES fibers. These studies will provide a knowledge base which will enhance the use of ES fiber materials in technologically important areas such as non-woven textiles, regenerative medicine, and transport and catalysis.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

Non-woven membranes will be created using very small diameter fibers, on the nano-scale, by applying a high electric field to a solution containing polymer and additives (such as carbon nanotubes or clay). Nanofibers formed this way are stronger and more heat resistant compared to conventional large diameter fibers. The processing conditions and nature of the additive will be varied to see which combinations yield nanofibers with the best properties. These non-woven fabrics are candidate materials for use as filtration membranes, in catalysis, for drug delivery, and as a component of smart clothing materials. Both national and international collaborations have been established for conducting this research using specialty equipment and novel processing conditions. To provide research opportunities for students with disabilities, four deaf and hard of hearing undergraduate students will participate in an internship, and perform research on the project during the summer months. These interns will learn to make the non-woven nanofibers, heat treat them, and study their physical properties.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

Polymer fiber composites that contain nano-scale inclusions can be used in a variety of technologies, for example, in biomedical engineering for guidance of cell growth, in pharmaceutics for delivery of drugs, and in filtrations and separations for provision of clean water. When these composites are made in the form of very small (nano-scale) diameter fibers incorporating nano-scale inclusions, some of their properties will be changed.  We investigated which properties change, and in what manner.  Specifically, we studied the crystallilne nature of the fibers using X-ray diffraction. We used scanning electron microscopy images to measure the fibers' diameters and assess their surface quality.  We used advanced methods of thermal analysis to show how they behave when they are heated. 

We made the fibers using a technique called "electrospinning". We formed polymer nanofibers of poly(L-lactic acid) (PLLA) and poly(vinyl alcohol), which are biocompatible and biodegradable polymers synthesized from renewable resources. As nano-scale inclusions, we selected multi-walled carbon nanotubes and the statin drug, LovastatinTM.  In the first instance, the carbon nanotubes were co-electrospun with the polymers creating highly aligned fibers whose diameter was significantly reduced compared to fibers that did not contain any nanotubes.  Figure 1 shows an image of aligned fibers.  The nanotubes also influenced the thermal properties, making the fibers more crystalline and more rigid.  These oriented fibers were effective in directing growth of fibroblasts and cortical neurons from rat embryos.  Both neurons and fibroblasts grew preferentially along the direction of aligned electrospun fibers.  Figure 2 shows the growth of neurons along the PLLA fiber direction.

We also perfected techniques of thermal analysis whereby films and fibers can be heated very rapidly, at rates of 2000 degrees Kelvin per second.  Using such fast heating, we are able to study how the fibers melt and crystallize without becoming degraded by too long exposure to high temperatures.

Our work is highly interdisciplinary and collaborative in nature. We have established collaborations with Dept. of Biomedical Engineering (for culturing and imaging the neurons) and with Chemical and Biological engineering (for testing our fiber membranes for use in separations technology.)

Broader Impact
Our studies have provided a knowledge base about polymeric fibers containing inclusions, enhancing the use of very small diameter fibers in advanced technologies. We have investigated use of these fibers as support structures for filtration membranes, scaffolds for neuron growth, and for drug delivery. We have developed analytical tools for performance of very fast heating studies.

The research provided education and training to 4 graduate students and 12 undergraduate students from Tufts, and 2 exchange students from the University of Ghana.

Continuing the unique outreach to deaf and hard of hearing students (DHH), 12 DHH interns (coming to Tufts from Gallaudet University, Rochester Institute of Technology's National Technical Institute for the Deaf, Texas A&M, University of Pennsylvania, Swarthmore, and Whitworth University) participated in classroom and laboratory research over the summer. Figure 3 shows the DHH interns from 2013 along with their teachers.

Dissemination of results occurred through 20 papers published in refereed journals, 2 Ph. D. dissertations, and 3 undergraduate student theses, numerous presentations, and the Cebe group’s website: http://www.tufts.edu/~pcebe


Last Modified: 09/28/2016
Modified by: Peggy Cebe
